caption:
A standard 50-mL capacity ultrafiltration (UF) cell 
(Pharmacia, Sweden) was converted into a continuous 
stirred reactor (Fig. 1). The UF cell was filled with 
50 mL of DEAE-cellulose immobilized microbial cell 
preparation suspended in 20 mM phosphate buffer 
(pH 6.4) at a density of 4 mg dry weight carrier/mL 
reactor volume. The top disc was sealed air tight, and 
two silicone rubber tubes (1 mm diameter) were in- 
serted from the inlet hole of the UF cell. One of the 
silicone tubes was extended to the bottom of the cell 
and connected to a sparger made of a hard, plastic tube 
(1 mm diameter) ring with holes along the periphery. 
The pressure release vent of the UF cell was replaced 
with a glass capillary connected through a rubber stop- 
per to be used as an outlet for the circulating gaseous

caption:
lar to that observed for free cells. The temperature data 
were replotted in the form of an Arrhenius plot to calcu- 
late activation energy (E,) for free and immobilized 
cells (Fig. 3). The values of E, for free and immobilized 
cells were computed to be 19,537 and 14,800 cal/mol, 
respectively. The optimum concentration of phosphate 
ions required for inhibition of methanol oxidation activ- 
ity was 100 mM, slightly higher than that required by 
the free cells (80 mM).7 Oxygen appeared to be the rate 
limiting substrate for methanol biosynthesis in immobi- 
lized cell preparations. The replacement of air with 
oxygen in batch cultures supported a total methanol ac- 
cumulation rate of 8.92 pmol/h mg cells, representing 
an increase in conversion efficiency over air supplied 
cells from 10% to 27% (Table I). This value is threefold 
higher than that reported by HOU" for propylene oxide 
synthesis using M. trichosporium OB3b. An increase in 
oxygen concentration was seen to result in decreased 
methane uptake rates. It has been reported that under 
oxygen excess (methane limiting) conditions, the en- 
zyme MMO in M. capsulatus and M. trichosporium 
OB3b switches from soluble to particulate form63l3 and 
may exhibit altered reaction specificities toward differ- 
ent substrates. This may be responsible for the observed 
phenomenon. 
The synthesis of methanol by immobilized cells was 
at a constant rate of 8.75 pmol/h mg cells for the first 
2.5 h (Fig. 4), and the rate fell sharply after 6 h. In our 
earlier studies with free cells, the fall in the methanol 
accumulation rate was attributed to depletion of the 
endogenous NADHz pool, and methanol accumulation 
rate was maximally stimulated by supplying 40 mM for- 
mate to the reaction ves~e1.I~ 
With immobilized cells, 
maximum stimulation in methanol accumulation rate to 
8.6 ,umol/h mg cells occurred on addition of 40 mM

caption:
The covalently linked immobilized cells produced 
methanol at a constant rate of 100 pmol/h in a 50-mL 
reactor containing 100 mg dry cell weight after attaining 
steady state (Fig. 5). This rate of methanol biosynthesis 
continued for 11 h after which a fall in the rate was 
observed. Based on earlier batch studies, this was at- 
tributed to depletion of intracellular NADH2 pool. The 
in vivo regeneration of NADH2 in the continuous reac- 
tor was carried out by supplying different concentrations 
of sodium formate in 20 or 100 mM phosphate buffer, 
and the results are shown in Figure 5. A continuous 
feed of 20 mM sodium formate in 100 mM phosphate 
buffer resulted in sustained methanol accumulation of 
267 pmol/h, giving a productivity of 5.34 mmol/h L. 
The reactor was maintained at this level of productivity 
for up to 70 h. 
The interrelationship between formate supply, 
NADHz regeneration, and methanol accumulation was

caption:
Figure 7. Operational stability of the immobilized cells in the 
continuous reactor: E/Eo, MMO activity measured at the indicated 
time divided by enzyme activity of freshly immobilized cells.
